questions.explanation: Multiplication has higher precedence, so 5 * 2 = 10, then 3 + 10 = 13.
The array has indices 0 to 2, so accessing index 3 throws an exception.
x % 2 == 0 checks if x is even, so for x = 4, it prints 'Even'.
substring(1, 3) extracts characters from index 1 to 2 (exclusive).
Java is case-sensitive; 'X' is undefined, only 'x' is defined.
The square method returns 4 * 4 = 16.
The length property returns the size of the array, which is 3.
The for loop is missing an opening brace { after the condition.
The '+' operator concatenates the strings 'Hello' and 'World'.
x += 3 adds 3 to x, so 10 + 3 = 13.
Calling length() on a null string causes a NullPointerException.
The loop finds 5 in the array and prints 'Found'.
Division by zero throws an ArithmeticException, caught by the catch block.
Parsing 'abc' as an integer throws a NumberFormatException.
The max method returns 7 since 7 > 3.
arr[2] accesses the third element, 'c'.
The main method must be lowercase 'main', not 'Main'.
The for loop iterates from 0 to 2, printing each number.
The ! operator negates true to false.
ArrayList cannot use primitive types; use Integer instead of int.
The add method appends 5 to the ArrayList, printed as [5].
toUpperCase() converts the string to uppercase.
Division by zero throws an ArithmeticException.
The doubleNum method returns 3 * 2 = 6.
Post-increment (x++) prints x (5) before incrementing.
String concatenation with 4 results in '1234', not an error.
The isEmpty() method returns true if the string length is 0.
Casting double to int truncates the decimal part, so 5.5 becomes 5.
A String cannot be assigned to an int variable.
The loop adds 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15.
charAt(1) returns the character at index 1, which is 'e'.
Unboxing a null Integer to int causes a NullPointerException.
The constructor sets the name field to 'Alice'.
The ternary operator returns 'Yes' since 3 > 2.
Division by zero throws an ArithmeticException.
The loop prints the array elements in reverse order.
length() returns the number of characters in 'Java'.
The array has indices 0 to 2, so index 3 is out of bounds.
equals() checks if the strings have the same content.
Pre-increment (++x) increments x before printing, so 5 becomes 6.
